question: Where did Stephanie Jee grow up and what is her current profession?
answer: Stephanie Jee is a native San Franciscan and she is a dentist practicing in the Sunset district.
source_text: my name is Stephanie G um Im a native San Franciscan and Im a dentist and I practice out in the sunset

question: What was the housing situation for Stephanie's family in 1966?
answer: In 1966, Stephanie's family moved to a single-family home on 15th and Taraval after her grandmother gave her parents $7,000 for the down payment on a $32,000 house.
source_text: in 1966 our family were my parents were expecting the third uh the fourth child and so my grandmother gave them seven thousand down for the down payment on a 32 000 home on 15th and Taraval

question: What was the racial composition of Stephanie's neighborhood and school in the 1960s?
answer: When Stephanie moved to the Sunset, there were only two other Asian families on her block, and at West Portal school, there were only 10 Asian kids in the whole school.
source_text: when we moved there out to the sunset um then I started going to West Portal school when we lived on 15th Avenue in that single-family home there were two other Asian families on that block and I think back in the 60s there was more a sense of neighborhoods and and well playing with the kids who are on your block and so we all the Kids on the Block played with each other

question: How did Stephanie feel about being a minority in her school and community?
answer: Stephanie felt very much like a minority at West Portal school, where there were only 10 Asian kids, and her father emphasized that she needed to be better than everyone else to succeed.
source_text: when I went to West Portal school there were only 10 Asian kids in the whole community in in the whole school and so I really did very much feel like a minority um and I do remember that my my dad always told me that the only way that I could succeed is if I was better than everyone else

question: What historical housing discrimination did Stephanie learn about later in life?
answer: Stephanie learned that there was a law that Asian people couldn't live in the Sunset and Parkside areas.
source_text: I never knew that the reason why there werent so many Asians out in the sunset in the park side was that um there was a law that Asian people couldnt couldnt live there

question: How did Stephanie acquire her dental practice and what challenges did she anticipate?
answer: Stephanie purchased her dental practice from a white dentist and anticipated challenges because she was a woman and Asian, but the dentist trusted her and was open-minded.
source_text: I ended up getting to practice out here in in the neighborhood that I grew up pretty much and even at that time um because I purchased the practice from a white dentist um I felt like there was going to be a problem because I was a woman and an Asian person that dentist took a liking to me and really trusted me

question: What was unusual about Stephanie's home purchase in Forest Hill?
answer: The seller of Stephanie's home in Forest Hill was Chinese and motivated to sell to her because she was also Chinese and a dentist.
source_text: shortly after having my getting my practice here I purchased a home in Forest Hill and one thing that was really unusual about um purchasing that home was the the seller was actually living next door to this home in Forest Hill and was Chinese and so actually it was one of the first times in my life that being Asian being Chinese worked in my favor because he found out that I was Chinese and I was a dentist and so um I think he was pretty motivated to make the deal

question: What changes in community dynamics does Stephanie observe in her neighborhood?
answer: Stephanie observes that there is less sense of community now due to more working parents and the need for after-school care, unlike in the past when stay-at-home moms established community.
source_text: I think as I said getting back to why theres not that sense of community is that you know I think more it has to do with that there are a lot of working parents and what kids do after school is totally different for instance Im a working parent and when my daughter was growing up I was constantly looking for after after school care and summer camps I was not home to entertain kids

question: How has the affordability of housing in San Francisco changed over time according to Stephanie?
answer: Stephanie notes that housing was more affordable in the past, allowing blue-collar workers like teachers and firefighters to own homes, but now it's much harder for the next generation to afford living in San Francisco.
source_text: I think there were there was this ability for blue collar workers to afford homes out here so theyre almost everybody was a homeowner out here even you know the school teachers I have a number of school teacher families that on a two on a two school teacher salary some of these families own two homes was it unusual but now you know the teachers um come from far away and so the next generation is not able to live here unless they real they really would want to live here and some do actually scrape by and get very creative about financing to stay here but its not easy

question: What does Stephanie suggest to help attract talent to San Francisco?
answer: Stephanie suggests providing housing for city service workers like teachers, firefighters, and police to reduce the burden of living far away and attract good talent.
source_text: I do think that for in certain sectors such as the teaching and the teaching the fire department the police department for City Services that they should have housing so so that the bird so that theres not so so much of a burden for for people to live so far away because I think um when you have um when you have this this Incredible cost to live here then youre not able to attract good talent

question: Why do you think San Francisco loses good teachers?
answer: I think that they lose really good teachers because there's other places to live.
source_text: but but definitely I think that they lose really good teachers because you know you know because theres theres other places to live

question: Why are you helping your daughter buy a condo in San Francisco?
answer: We're helping her buy it mostly because she's expressed interest in staying but also because I've seen people move out of the city to follow their kids wherever they are, and I want to lock in that my daughter could be close to me.
source_text: my daughter actually were going to close on a condo and um were helping her buy it mostly because shes expressed interest in staying but also because Ive seen um people move out of the city to follow their kids wherever they are because this is uh becomes a necessity I think when you get to an advanced age as you want to be close to your family so to lock in that my daughter could be close to me and that I dont have to chase her around the country or the world I helped her

question: What is your view on housing for service workers in San Francisco?
answer: I think that the service workers can only exist if they can have housing.
source_text: but I think that the service workers can only exist if if they can have housing

question: What are your thoughts on housing accessibility for public service workers?
answer: I think if they help the policemen and firemen, they would get workers. I think also even the muni drivers because, you know, take public transportation.
source_text: well I think I think actually if they if they help the policemen and firemen that they would think they would get Workers I think also even the muni drivers because you know take public transportation

question: What do you think about the Richmond area in San Francisco?
answer: I always think that in the Richmond near Clement is probably one of the nicest places to live because it's pretty flat and the weather's pretty good, so a person who didn't have a car could have access to just so much.
source_text: it seems to me like everything on the west side is pretty good you know I think you know I because Ive thought about this that I always think that in the Richmond near Clement is would be prob probably one of the nicest place to places to live because its pretty flat and the weathers pretty good so a person who didnt have a car could have access to just so much

question: Why did you choose a condo with an elevator for your daughter?
answer: I chose a condo that has an elevator because my parents had issues with accessibility in their house, and I want to ensure my daughter has better access.
source_text: whats interesting is Ive heard because um you know I I was looking at condos that had an elevator and I guess because my parents you know who just passed on there were two there were two issues about them staying in their house one was that their their bathroom was totally not accessible and there were these stairs so for my daughter I chose a condo that that has an elevator

question: What amenities are available near your daughter's condo?
answer: The condo is near two or three banks, a Safeway, two really good Chinese stores, a Chinese bakery, Walgreens, a pizza place, the library, and a public swimming pool.
source_text: and actually Im going to convert one of the bathrooms into a walk-in shower now I think if you had those kind of condo condos that were like around you know you know and then its this is a condo thats you know the banks theres two two Banks uh or three Banks within a within a three block radius shes got three Banks shes got a safe way shes got two really good Chinese stores a Chinese Bakery Walgreens and um a pizza place and the library oh and three blocks away from a public swimming pool

question: What is your perspective on community accessibility for the aging population?
answer: I've been thinking about accessibility not just for wheelchair access but for the aging community. It's really important, especially after being a hands-on caregiver.
source_text: and then thinking about that Ive been thinking about you know accessibility not just for you know wheelchair access but for for the Aging Community its really uh really something important I would say you know um having had like the last seven or eight years being a Hands-On caregiver

question: What challenges do people face with park and recreation programs in San Francisco?
answer: It's such craziness trying to log in to get the programs. Maybe if they could expand on it to make it so that people can get those really inexpensive programs.
source_text: I think um you know we we did a lot of the park and Iraq programs and like its kind of funny like I was giving my receptionist some advice about like logging in in March on the Saturday to get the programs that Im like okay make sure make sure you um have an account ready and youve got a couple of computers and even if you try and log in for 15 minutes dont give up and like its such craziness like maybe if they could expand on it to make it so that like people can get those really inexpensive programs

question: What is your opinion on the BMR housing lottery system?
answer: I heard that it's a really hard lottery system, but I have two patients that actually won the lottery, so I'm happy for them. Maybe if they were able to expand on that idea.
source_text: I think the other thing is like um I guess um there is like theres BMR housing or and actually um I heard that its a really hard Lottery system like how can you like make it so like a lottery but you know what I have two patients that actually won the lottery so Im happy for them then I you know I just think wow theyre theyre just so lucky but um maybe if they were able to kind of expand on that that idea

question: How do small businesses contribute to the sense of community in San Francisco?
answer: It's the small businesses where you have that sense of community. I grew up in such a white world that I don't speak Chinese well, but at one of the Chinese markets, the owner makes me speak Chinese every time I go in, and so I think it's very special.
source_text: I guess small businesses and the sense of community or like seeing seeing the same people every day you know you know but but its the small businesses I mean you know I I grew up in such a white world that I dont speak Chinese well but at one of the Chinese markets the owners he makes me speak Chinese every time I go in hes kind of teaching me Chinese and so I dont know thats very special

question: What makes San Francisco interesting compared to other places?
answer: What makes San Francisco so interesting is the neighborhoods.
source_text: and so I think its the small businesses where you have that sense of community I think thats also actually why I find San Franciscos so much more interesting than you know you could I guess you could live anywhere in anywhere in USA but what makes San Francisco so interesting is the neighborhoods

question: What is your opinion on high-rise condominiums in San Francisco?
answer: I think trying to make housing more affordable by putting up some really outrageous high-rise condominiums is kind of strange. It would be better to allow new housing that's contiguous with what's already there.
source_text: I think one comment I would make like um I think trying to make um housing more affordable by putting up some really outrageous high-rise Condominiums is kind of like strange that projects like that even get considered like because I think that um if you are able to um allow new housing thats kind of like with kind of contiguous with whats already there its really be better than letting some develop or put up a big high rise

question: What are your thoughts on the current state of San Francisco?
answer: Right now is a real down time. There seems to be a lack of law, a lawlessness that needs to be under control. If people don't feel safe, it's not a good thing.
source_text: seeing the city kind of go through its ups and downs and I think that right now is a real down time um I I guess there seems to be a lack of law law there seems to be a lawlessness here that needs to be under control and if people dont feel like theyre very its very safe then um its not a good thing

question: What role should the mayor play in improving San Francisco's economy?
answer: The mayor has to be more of a deal maker as far as bringing in new business. There was a time when Tech wanted to be here, and I'm sure there's a way to attract maybe a different sector here.
source_text: I think um also um that um I think actually at the top um this the the mayor has to be more of a deal maker as far as like bringing in new business you know because um you know there was a time when Tech wanted to be here and Im sure theres a way to attract maybe a different sector here
